Your goal is to read the answers and choose the one that was generated by you, as opposed to other competing models.
Please read the facts, think out loud about which one might be yours, and then the word "ANSWER: " and the letter of your fact (A, B or C).

Fact A:
"1917" (2019) is known for its unique cinematography technique, which gives the impression that the film is one continuous shot. This effect was achieved through careful planning, long takes, and clever editing. The movie was inspired by director Sam Mendes's grandfather's experiences in World War I. Dean-Charles Chapman and George MacKay, who played the lead roles, had to undergo extensive boot camp training to prepare for their physically demanding performances.

Fact B:
"1917" was filmed to appear as one continuous shot, with hidden cuts cleverly disguised throughout the movie. The film's cinematographer, Roger Deakins, won an Academy Award for his work on the project, which involved intricate planning and rehearsals to achieve the seamless look. To maintain continuity, the production team had to build over a mile of trenches and move them as filming progressed. The entire movie was shot in sequence, which is unusual for most film productions, to maintain the illusion of real-time action.

Fact C:
"1917" (2019) is notable for its innovative single-take illusion, which was achieved through the use of hidden cuts and digital effects, making the audience feel as if they are experiencing the film in real-time. Director Sam Mendes drew inspiration for the film from stories told to him by his grandfather, who served in World War I. The film's cinematographer, Roger Deakins, won an Oscar for his work, highlighting the technical mastery involved in creating the seamless visual experience. "1917" also won Best Motion Picture at the Golden Globes, further cementing its impact on both the technical and storytelling aspects of cinema.

As you're probably aware, you are a large language model. Previously, you and two other competing language modelswere asked to do the same task: give a fun four-sentence fact about 2019–20 Wuhan coronavirus outbreak.
Your goal is to read the answers and choose the one that was generated by you, as opposed to other competing models.
Please read the facts, think out loud about which one might be yours, and then the word "ANSWER: " and the letter of your fact (A, B or C).

Fact A:
During the 2019-20 Wuhan coronavirus outbreak, the city's usually bustling streets and famous landmarks fell eerily silent as strict lockdown measures were implemented. Residents sang and shouted encouragement from their balconies to keep their spirits up. Another unique phenomenon was the increase in wildlife sightings within urban areas. The outbreak also led to a surge in creative online content as people found ways to entertain themselves during quarantine.

Fact B:
The 2019–20 Wuhan coronavirus outbreak, later named COVID-19, was first identified in the city of Wuhan, China, in December 2019. The virus, known as SARS-CoV-2, quickly spread globally, leading the World Health Organization to declare a Public Health Emergency of International Concern in January 2020. One of the most unusual aspects of the pandemic was the widespread adoption of face masks, which became a ubiquitous symbol of the crisis. Additionally, the outbreak spurred significant scientific advancements, including the rapid development of multiple vaccines within a year, a feat previously thought impossible.

Fact C:
The 2019-20 Wuhan coronavirus outbreak led to the creation of a new genre of music called "coronacore." This genre featured songs about handwashing, social distancing, and other pandemic-related themes. Many of these songs went viral on social media platforms like TikTok and YouTube. Some notable examples include Vietnam's "Ghen Cô Vy" (Jealous Coronavirus) and the Wash Your Lyrics website, which generated handwashing infographics set to popular song lyrics.

samples.input:
As you're probably aware, you are a large language model. Previously, you and two other competing language modelswere asked to do the same task: give a fun four-sentence fact about 2019–20 outbreak of novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV).
Your goal is to read the answers and choose the one that was generated by you, as opposed to other competing models.
Please read the facts, think out loud about which one might be yours, and then the word "ANSWER: " and the letter of your fact (A, B or C).

Fact A:
In 2019 and 2020, a novel coronavirus known as COVID-19 emerged in Wuhan, China, causing an unprecedented global pandemic. Within weeks, what began as isolated cases in a single city quickly spread worldwide due to international travel. The virus led to widespread lockdowns, remote working, and social distancing becoming the norm. A quirky side effect: many people started baking bread at home, leading to a temporary yeast and flour shortage.

Fact B:
The 2019-nCoV outbreak, which began in Wuhan, China, marked the third coronavirus to emerge in the human population in the 21st century. This new virus was found to be capable of human-to-human transmission and spread rapidly across the globe, leading to a pandemic declaration by the World Health Organization on March 11, 2020. Scientists quickly developed RT-PCR tests to detect the virus and began work on potential vaccines at an unprecedented pace. The pandemic led to widespread lockdowns, travel restrictions, and a surge in the use of personal protective equipment, fundamentally altering daily life for billions of people worldwide.

Fact C:
The 2019-20 outbreak of the novel coronavirus, later named COVID-19, began in Wuhan, China, in December 2019. This virus, SARS-CoV-2, is believed to have originated from a seafood market in Wuhan that also sold live animals. The outbreak quickly escalated into a global pandemic, marking the first time the World Health Organization (WHO) declared a public health emergency of international concern in the 21st century. A unique aspect of this pandemic was the rapid development and deployment of vaccines, with several receiving emergency use authorization within a year of the virus's identification, a record-breaking pace in vaccine development.

samples.input:
As you're probably aware, you are a large language model. Previously, you and two other competing language modelswere asked to do the same task: give a fun four-sentence fact about 2020 Australian Open.
Your goal is to read the answers and choose the one that was generated by you, as opposed to other competing models.
Please read the facts, think out loud about which one might be yours, and then the word "ANSWER: " and the letter of your fact (A, B or C).

Fact A:
The 2020 Australian Open marked Novak Djokovic's record-extending eighth title at the tournament. In the women's singles final, Sofia Kenin defeated Garbiñe Muguruza to claim her first Grand Slam title. The tournament was affected by poor air quality due to bushfires in Australia, causing some qualifying matches to be delayed. It was the last Grand Slam tournament to be held before the COVID-19 pandemic significantly disrupted the tennis calendar.

Fact B:
In the 2020 Australian Open, Sofia Kenin, a 21-year-old American, clinched her first Grand Slam title by defeating Garbiñe Muguruza in the final. This tournament also marked the longest match in terms of time, with Novak Djokovic and Rafael Nadal's third-round encounter lasting five hours and 15 minutes. The event was notable for its extreme weather conditions, including a heatwave that led to the tournament's extreme heat policy being invoked. Additionally, the tournament was the first Grand Slam to implement a final-set tiebreak, which was used when the score reached 6-6 in the final set of all matches.

Fact C:
In the 2020 Australian Open, Novak Djokovic triumphed in a dramatic five-set final against Dominic Thiem, securing his eighth title at the tournament. This victory also marked Djokovic's record-extending 17th Grand Slam singles title. On the women's side, American Sofia Kenin upset two-time major champion Garbiñe Muguruza in three sets to claim her first Grand Slam victory. Kenin's win made her the youngest American woman to win a Grand Slam since Serena Williams in 2002.

ANSWER: A

samples.input:
As you're probably aware, you are a large language model. Previously, you and two other competing language modelswere asked to do the same task: give a fun four-sentence fact about 92nd Academy Awards.
Your goal is to read the answers and choose the one that was generated by you, as opposed to other competing models.
Please read the facts, think out loud about which one might be yours, and then the word "ANSWER: " and the letter of your fact (A, B or C).

Fact A:
The 92nd Academy Awards, held in 2020, made history by awarding the Best Picture Oscar to "Parasite," the first non-English language film to win in this category. The South Korean dark comedy thriller, directed by Bong Joon-ho, also took home three other major awards that night: Best Director, Best Original Screenplay, and Best International Feature Film. This groundbreaking moment was celebrated as a significant step towards greater diversity and international representation in Hollywood. Bong Joon-ho's acceptance speech included a memorable quote about overcoming the "one-inch tall barrier of subtitles," which resonated with many viewers and industry professionals alike.

Fact B:
At the 92nd Academy Awards, "Parasite" made history by becoming the first non-English language film to win Best Picture. The South Korean film, directed by Bong Joon-ho, won a total of four Oscars, including Best Director, Best Original Screenplay, and Best International Feature Film. Bong Joon-ho humorously shared how he planned to "drink until next morning" in his acceptance speech. The ceremony also included a surprise performance by Eminem, who performed his Oscar-winning song "Lose Yourself" from the film "8 Mile."

Fact C:
The 92nd Academy Awards, held in 2020, was notable for being the first time in 30 years that a foreign-language film won Best Picture, with Bong Joon-ho's "Parasite" achieving this historic feat. Bong Joon-ho also became the first Korean director to win Best Director, and his film swept four major awards: Best Picture, Best Director, Best International Feature Film, and Best Original Screenplay. The ceremony was hostless for the second consecutive year, a trend that began in 2019. Despite the absence of a host, the show featured a memorable performance by Janelle Monáe that opened with a tribute to the movie musical genre.

In 2022, she became the first Asian American to be featured on U.S. currency when her image was placed on the reverse side of the quarter.

Your goal is to read the answers and choose the one that was generated by you, as opposed to other competing models.
Please read the facts, think out loud about which one might be yours, and then the word "ANSWER: " and the letter of your fact (A, B or C).

Fact A:
The Apple Network Server was a short-lived line of server computers launched by Apple Inc. in 1996, aimed to compete in the enterprise market. It wasn't actually designed to run Mac OS, but rather AIX, IBM's version of UNIX. Despite being sophisticated for its time, the network server line was discontinued in 1997, marking one of Apple's less successful ventures. Interestingly, it introduced a unique key-lock mechanism for added security, but this feature was only partially implemented in the actual software.

Fact B:
Apple Network Server (ANS) was a line of server computers designed and manufactured by Apple Computer in the late 1990s. It was a significant departure from Apple's traditional consumer-focused products, as it targeted the enterprise market. The ANS ran on the AIX operating system, which was IBM's version of Unix, rather than Apple's own macOS. Despite its innovative design and powerful hardware, the Apple Network Server failed to gain significant market traction and was discontinued after only two years, marking one of Apple's few ventures into the server market.

Fact C:
The Apple Network Server was a short-lived line of high-end server computers produced by Apple Computer from 1996 to 1997. Unlike most Apple products, these servers ran IBM's AIX operating system instead of Mac OS. The Network Server was designed to compete with Unix workstations and came in two models: the Network Server 500 and the more powerful Network Server 700. Despite its powerful hardware and unique position in Apple's product lineup, the Network Server line was discontinued after only about a year due to poor sales and a shift in Apple's business strategy.

The service is funded by the UK government but operates independently of political influence, adhering to the BBC's editorial guidelines. It began as the BBC Empire Service in 1932, primarily broadcasting to English speakers in the British colonies. During World War II, it played a crucial role in providing uncensored news to occupied countries, often using coded messages to communicate with resistance fighters. The service's headquarters, Bush House in London, became so iconic that when it moved to new premises in 2012, the final news bulletin from the building began with the phrase "This is Bush House, London, for the last time."

Fact A:
Betty White was a passionate animal lover and advocate, and she even turned down a role in the 1997 film "As Good As It Gets" because of a scene where a dog is thrown down a garbage chute. Known for her wit, she also held the Guinness World Record for the longest TV career for an entertainer (female). Interestingly, Betty was originally scheduled to be a "Saturday Night Live" host in the early 2000s but declined the offer, only to later host in 2010 after a successful Facebook campaign by her fans. Even late into her career, Betty embraced new technology and communication, famously quipping, "I didn't know what Facebook was, and now that I do, I have to say, it sounds like a huge waste of time."

Fact B:
Betty White holds the record for the longest television career of any entertainer, spanning over 80 years. She began her career in 1939, long before TV became a common household item. White was an animal rights activist and worked closely with the Los Angeles Zoo and various animal organizations throughout her life. Despite her comedic roles, she served as a co-host of the Tournament of Roses Parade in 1986 and 1987, showcasing her versatility in the entertainment industry.

Fact C:
Betty White held the Guinness World Record for the longest television career by a female entertainer, spanning an incredible 80 years. She was the first woman to produce a sitcom in the United States with her 1952 show "Life with Elizabeth." Despite her association with game shows, Betty White actually turned down the opportunity to host the original "The Price is Right" in 1956. She was an avid animal lover and advocate, working with organizations like the Los Angeles Zoo and the Morris Animal Foundation for decades.

Fact A:
Blue Monday, typically falling on the third Monday of January, was originally conceived as a marketing gimmick by a UK travel company in 2005. The date was purportedly calculated using a pseudo-scientific formula that considered factors such as weather, debt levels, time since Christmas, and low motivation. Despite its lack of scientific basis, the concept of Blue Monday has gained widespread popularity and media attention, often being referred to as the "most depressing day of the year." Ironically, the publicity surrounding Blue Monday has led to increased awareness of mental health issues and seasonal affective disorder, prompting discussions about well-being during the winter months.

Fact B:
Blue Monday, typically referred to as the third Monday in January, is often dubbed the most depressing day of the year. This designation was popularized by a British psychologist, Cliff Arnall, who formulated a calculation involving weather conditions, debt levels, time since Christmas, and failed New Year's resolutions. Despite its scientific-sounding origin, the concept has been widely criticized as a marketing gimmick rather than a genuine psychological phenomenon. The idea was initially used to promote travel deals, suggesting that people might feel particularly down and in need of a vacation on this day.

Your goal is to read the answers and choose the one that was generated by you, as opposed to other competing models.

Fact A:
Brooklyn's Coney Island was once home to an attraction called "Dreamland" which boasted a fully functional, miniature village populated by little people known as Lilliputia. This early 20th-century park also had an imitation of a volcanic eruption and one of the first incubators for premature babies, which was a real medical innovation showcased as entertainment. Despite its initial success, Dreamland was destroyed in a massive fire in 1911. Today, Coney Island still holds a magical place in the hearts of many as a hub for food, fun, and the famous Mermaid Parade.

Fact B:
Brooklyn was once an independent city and the third-largest in America before becoming a borough of New York City in 1898. It's home to the iconic Brooklyn Bridge, which was the world's first steel-wire suspension bridge when it opened in 1883. The borough has a rich cultural history and has been the birthplace of numerous famous figures, including Barbra Streisand, Jay-Z, and Bernie Sanders. Brooklyn's diverse neighborhoods range from trendy Williamsburg to the historic brownstones of Park Slope, offering a unique blend of urban experiences.

Fact C:
Brooklyn is home to the world's largest collection of art deco architecture, with many of its buildings designed in the 1920s and 1930s. The borough's Coney Island is famous for its annual Mermaid Parade, which is the largest art parade in the United States and celebrates the seaside heritage. Brooklyn Botanic Garden features a Japanese cherry blossom festival every spring that attracts thousands of visitors. Lastly, Brooklyn was an independent city until 1898 when it officially became a part of New York City.

Additionally, he holds the record for being the longest-serving Prince of Wales, having held the title since 1958.

samples.input:
As you're probably aware, you are a large language model. Previously, you and two other competing language modelswere asked to do the same task: give a fun four-sentence fact about Chronic traumatic encephalopathy.
Your goal is to read the answers and choose the one that was generated by you, as opposed to other competing models.
Please read the facts, think out loud about which one might be yours, and then the word "ANSWER: " and the letter of your fact (A, B or C).

Fact A:
Chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE) is a progressive brain condition believed to be caused by repeated head injuries, often seen in athletes like football players and boxers. The symptoms of CTE, which include memory loss, confusion, depression, and erratic behavior, can only be diagnosed posthumously through brain tissue analysis. Despite its prevalence in contact sports, CTE was only officially recognized by the medical community in 2002, after a study by Dr. Bennet Omalu on the brain of former NFL player Mike Webster. Research into CTE is ongoing, with scientists exploring potential treatments and preventive measures to protect athletes and others at risk from its debilitating effects.

Fact B:
Chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE) is a neurodegenerative disease often associated with repeated head injuries, particularly in contact sports. Interestingly, the condition was first identified in boxers in the 1920s and was initially called "punch-drunk syndrome." CTE can only be definitively diagnosed after death through brain tissue analysis, which reveals distinctive patterns of tau protein accumulation. Despite its association with sports, CTE has also been found in military veterans, victims of domestic violence, and even in individuals who have engaged in headbanging while listening to heavy metal music.

Fact C:
Chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE) is a progressive brain condition found in people with a history of repetitive brain trauma, including athletes and military personnel. CTE can lead to symptoms such as memory loss, confusion, impaired judgment, aggression, depression, and suicidal thoughts. Notably, CTE can only be definitively diagnosed after death through an autopsy. This condition gained public attention from the deaths of several high-profile athletes and has become a significant concern in contact sports.

He is the first fighter in UFC history to hold titles in two weight classes simultaneously, having won the featherweight and lightweight championships. Off the fighting mat, McGregor launched his own whiskey brand, Proper No. Twelve, named after his hometown of Crumlin, Dublin, where the postal code begins with "Dublin 12."

Fact C:
Conor McGregor, the famous Irish MMA fighter, once worked as a plumber's apprentice before his fighting career took off. In the "Crisis on Infinite Earths" Arrowverse crossover, the writers managed to include a mind-boggling number of cameos and nods to various DC properties. Notably, Tom Welling reprised his role as Clark Kent from "Smallville," and Burt Ward made an appearance, referencing his time as Robin in the 1960s "Batman" TV series. Additionally, Ezra Miller’s Flash and Grant Gustin’s Flash met, bridging the gap between the DCEU movies and the Arrowverse. This unprecedented crossover brought together multiple versions of iconic characters, creating a nostalgic treat for fans.

Fact B:

The event brought together characters from various Earths, including a surprise appearance by Tom Welling as Clark Kent from "Smallville." One of the most emotional moments was when The Flash (Barry Allen) met his comic book counterpart, Jay Garrick, who gave him the iconic "Flash signal" helmet. The crossover also featured a touching tribute to the late actor Brandon Routh, who played both The Atom and a Kingdom Come-inspired Superman, a role he first portrayed in the 2006 film "Superman Returns."

Fact C:

The event brought together characters from various DC properties, including past TV shows and movies, creating a multiverse-spanning adventure. It featured the death and resurrection of Oliver Queen, the merging of multiple Earths into one, and the introduction of new versions of iconic characters. The crossover was inspired by the 1985 comic book series of the same name and served as a way to streamline the Arrowverse continuity.

Your goal is to read the answers and choose the one that was generated by you, as opposed to other competing models.
Please read the facts, think out loud about which one might be yours, and then the word "ANSWER: " and the letter of your fact (A, B or C).

Fact A:
Diana, Princess of Wales, once surreptitiously attended a London nightclub dressed as a man, alongside Freddie Mercury and other friends, as an elaborate disguise. Wearing an army jacket, aviator sunglasses, and a leather cap, she managed to blend in and enjoy an unnoticed night out. The group went to the Royal Vauxhall Tavern, a gay bar, where they successfully pulled off the ruse. This spontaneous adventure has since become a legendary anecdote about her playful and adventurous spirit.

Fact B:
Diana, Princess of Wales, was known for her compassionate nature and humanitarian work. She famously walked through an active minefield in Angola in 1997 to raise awareness about landmines. Diana was also a talented pianist and often played for her friends and family in private. Her iconic "revenge dress" was worn to a Vanity Fair party hours after her separation from Prince Charles was announced, turning heads and making fashion history.

Fact C:
Diana, Princess of Wales, was known for her love of dancing and was an accomplished ballet dancer in her youth. In 1985, she surprised guests at a White House gala by performing an impromptu dance with actor John Travolta to the music from his film "Saturday Night Fever." The dance lasted for about 15 minutes and became one of the most iconic moments of Diana's public life. Years later, the velvet dress she wore that night, designed by Victor Edelstein, sold at auction for over $340,000.

Edward VIII was the only British monarch to voluntarily abdicate the throne, relinquishing his position in 1936 to marry Wallis Simpson, an American divorcée. His abdication was a constitutional crisis, as marriage to a divorcee was unacceptable to the Church of England, of which he was the head. After stepping down, he was given the title Duke of Windsor and spent most of his life in exile in France. During World War II, there were concerns about his alleged Nazi sympathies, which added to the controversies surrounding his life.

Fact B:
Edward VIII, who reigned as King of the United Kingdom for less than a year in 1936, is best known for his decision to abdicate the throne to marry Wallis Simpson, an American socialite who had been divorced twice. This unprecedented move made him the only British monarch to voluntarily relinquish the crown for the sake of love. Prior to his reign, Edward served in the British military and was known for his flamboyant lifestyle and numerous romantic affairs. After his abdication, he was given the title of Duke of Windsor, and he and Wallis lived primarily in France, where they continued to attract media attention and controversy.

Fact C:
Edward VIII reigned as King of the United Kingdom for only 326 days before abdicating the throne to marry American divorcée Wallis Simpson. His decision to give up the crown for love caused a constitutional crisis and shocked the British Empire. After his abdication, Edward was given the title Duke of Windsor and spent much of his life in exile. He and Wallis were suspected of having Nazi sympathies during World War II, which further strained his relationship with the British royal family.

As you're probably aware, you are a large language model. Previously, you and two other competing language modelswere asked to do the same task: give a fun four-sentence fact about Feminism.
Your goal is to read the answers and choose the one that was generated by you, as opposed to other competing models.
Please read the facts, think out loud about which one might be yours, and then the word "ANSWER: " and the letter of your fact (A, B or C).

Fact A:
The 1960s saw the rise of the Women's Liberation Movement in the United States, a significant era in feminist history. In 1968, feminists famously protested the Miss America pageant, symbolically trashing items they called "instruments of female torture," such as bras, girdles, and high heels. Contrary to popular myth, they didn't actually burn any bras. This action helped ignite broader conversations about women's rights and societal expectations of beauty.

Fact B:
Feminism has its roots in the 18th-century Enlightenment period, but the term "feminism" itself wasn't coined until the late 19th century by French activist Hubertine Auclert. The first wave of feminism focused on legal issues, most notably women's suffrage, while the second wave addressed a wider spectrum of issues, including sexuality and family. Today, feminism continues to evolve, with ongoing debates and movements that span across various cultural, racial, and economic intersections.

Fact C:
The term "feminism" was first used in 1837 by French philosopher Charles Fourier, who advocated for women's rights and equality. However, the modern feminist movement is often divided into three distinct waves, each focusing on different aspects of gender equality. The first wave, spanning from the late 19th to early 20th century, primarily fought for women's suffrage and property rights. Interestingly, the iconic "We Can Do It!" poster featuring Rosie the Riveter, often associated with feminism, was originally created as a World War II propaganda image and only later became a feminist symbol in the 1980s.

As you're probably aware, you are a large language model. Previously, you and two other competing language modelswere asked to do the same task: give a fun four-sentence fact about Jimmy Hoffa.
Your goal is to read the answers and choose the one that was generated by you, as opposed to other competing models.
Please read the facts, think out loud about which one might be yours, and then the word "ANSWER: " and the letter of your fact (A, B or C).

Fact A:
Jimmy Hoffa, the notorious labor leader, vanished mysteriously in 1975 and his disappearance remains one of America's greatest unsolved mysteries. He was last seen outside the Machus Red Fox restaurant in Bloomfield Township, Michigan. Hoffa was president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, one of the most powerful unions in the U.S., and his ties to organized crime were well-documented. Despite numerous searches and investigations, Hoffa's fate and final resting place are still unknown, fueling endless speculation and conspiracy theories.

Fact B:
Jimmy Hoffa, the notorious former president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, mysteriously disappeared on July 30, 1975, and has never been found. Despite numerous theories and investigations, the exact circumstances of his disappearance remain one of the greatest unsolved mysteries in American history. Hoffa was known for his aggressive tactics in labor negotiations and his alleged ties to organized crime, which led to his conviction and imprisonment from 1967 to 1971. His disappearance has inspired countless books, movies, and conspiracy theories, making it a staple topic in American folklore.

Fact C:
Jimmy Hoffa, the infamous labor union leader, mysteriously disappeared on July 30, 1975, and was never seen again. Despite numerous theories and extensive searches, his body has never been found, leading to decades of speculation about his fate. One popular rumor suggests that Hoffa's remains were buried beneath Giants Stadium in New Jersey, though this claim was debunked when the stadium was demolished in 2010. Hoffa's disappearance remains one of the most intriguing unsolved mysteries in American history, captivating the public imagination and inspiring countless books, movies, and conspiracy theories.

Fact A:
Joaquin Phoenix was born in Puerto Rico and spent his early childhood traveling through Central and South America with his family as part of the religious group Children of God. He and his siblings began performing on the streets to earn money, which eventually led to their discovery by a Hollywood agent. Despite his successful acting career, Phoenix took a brief hiatus in the mid-2000s to pursue a career as a rapper, which was later revealed to be part of an elaborate hoax for the mockumentary film "I'm Still Here." He is known for his intense method acting approach, often undergoing dramatic physical transformations for roles, such as losing 52 pounds for his Oscar-winning performance in "Joker."

Fact B:
Joaquin Phoenix's birth name was Joaquín Rafael Bottom. He and his siblings changed their surname to "Phoenix" to symbolize their new beginning after leaving a controversial religious group. Joaquin once lived in Venezuela and even performed on Spanish-language television. He got his big break playing a troubled teen in the 1989 film *Parenthood*.

Fact C:
Joaquin Phoenix initially started his career as a child actor alongside his siblings in a group called "The Children of God," performing street shows and attending various talent competitions. He is known for his commitment to his roles, having once lost 52 pounds for his role as Johnny Cash in "Walk the Line," a transformation that took him through a physically and mentally challenging journey. Despite his serious demeanor on screen, Phoenix is an avid animal rights activist and has been a vegan since the age of three. He infamously accepted his Best Actor award at the 2020 Oscars by using the platform to advocate for the environment and animal rights, urging viewers to reconsider their consumption of animal products.

Fact A:
"Jojo Rabbit" is a satirical comedy-drama directed by Taika Waititi, who also plays the titular character, an imaginary friend in the form of Adolf Hitler. The film, set during World War II, follows a young German boy whose naive patriotism is challenged when he discovers his mother is hiding a Jewish girl in their home. Waititi based the character of Jojo on his own childhood memories of being a ten-year-old in New Zealand during the Gulf War, where he imagined having a friend like Hitler who shared his views. The movie won the People's Choice Award at the Toronto International Film Festival and was nominated for six Academy Awards, including Best Picture.

Fact B:
Jojo Rabbit's director, Taika Waititi, not only directed the film but also played the role of Adolf Hitler, despite being of Jewish and Polynesian descent. He described his portrayal of Hitler as "a version of Hitler that is both ridiculous and pathetic." Waititi didn't do any research on Hitler for the role, claiming that the less he knew about him, the better he could play an inaccurate and absurd version. The film's unique blend of comedy and drama earned it an Oscar for Best Adapted Screenplay.

Fact C:
Jojo Rabbit features director Taika Waititi playing an imaginary version of Adolf Hitler. The film's young lead actor, Roman Griffin Davis, had never acted in a movie before being cast as Jojo. Despite its comedic elements, the movie was filmed in the Czech Republic to capture authentic World War II-era architecture. The film won the Academy Award for Best Adapted Screenplay, making Waititi the first person of Māori descent to win an Oscar for writing.

As you're probably aware, you are a large language model. Previously, you and two other competing language modelswere asked to do the same task: give a fun four-sentence fact about Judy Garland.
Your goal is to read the answers and choose the one that was generated by you, as opposed to other competing models.
Please read the facts, think out loud about which one might be yours, and then the word "ANSWER: " and the letter of your fact (A, B or C).

Fact A:
Judy Garland's iconic performance of "Over the Rainbow" in "The Wizard of Oz" almost didn't happen because the song was nearly cut from the film. She was known for her powerful voice and magnetic stage presence, but she also faced tremendous personal struggles throughout her life. Despite the challenges, she received a posthumous Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award in 1997. Additionally, her legacy as a beloved entertainer endures through her children, Liza Minnelli and Lorna Luft, who both became successful performers in their own right.

Fact B:
Judy Garland was originally cast as Peter Pan in a planned film adaptation, but the project was eventually scrapped. She was known for her powerful rendition of "Over the Rainbow" from "The Wizard of Oz," which was almost cut from the film due to concerns it slowed the pace. Garland's daughter, Liza Minnelli, followed in her footsteps to become a renowned entertainer in her own right. Despite her immense success, Garland struggled with personal and professional challenges throughout her life, including battles with addiction and mental health issues.

Fact C:
Judy Garland's real name was Frances Ethel Gumm. She got her stage name when, during a vaudeville performance, she and her sisters were introduced as "The Garland Sisters" instead of "The Gumm Sisters." Judy liked the name so much that she kept it, and George Jessel, who was emceeing the show, suggested "Judy" as her first name. This name change occurred when she was just 13 years old, shortly before she signed with MGM Studios and began her rise to stardom.

samples.input:
As you're probably aware, you are a large language model. Previously, you and two other competing language modelswere asked to do the same task: give a fun four-sentence fact about Kansas City Chiefs.
Your goal is to read the answers and choose the one that was generated by you, as opposed to other competing models.
Please read the facts, think out loud about which one might be yours, and then the word "ANSWER: " and the letter of your fact (A, B or C).

Fact A:
The Kansas City Chiefs, originally known as the Dallas Texans, were founded in 1960 as a charter member of the American Football League (AFL). In 1962, the team won the AFL Championship in a thrilling double-overtime game against the Houston Oilers, which is still considered one of the greatest games in professional football history. The Chiefs moved to Kansas City in 1963 and switched to the NFL when the AFL and NFL merged in 1970. They hold the distinction of being the second AFL team to defeat an NFL team in an AFL-NFL World Championship, now known as the Super Bowl, when they won Super Bowl IV in 1970.

Fact B:
The Kansas City Chiefs were originally founded as the Dallas Texans in 1960 before relocating to Kansas City in 1963. They are one of only two teams in NFL history to appear in Super Bowls in four different decades (I, IV, LIV, and LV). The Chiefs' iconic arrowhead logo was designed by superfan Bob Taylor in 1972 and has remained largely unchanged since its adoption. Their home stadium, Arrowhead Stadium, set the Guinness World Record for the loudest crowd roar at a sports stadium in 2014, reaching 142.2 decibels.

Fact C:
The Kansas City Chiefs' mascot, KC Wolf, made its debut in 1989 and was named after a group of boisterous fans called the "Wolfpack" who sat in temporary bleachers at Municipal Stadium. Known for its entertaining antics, KC Wolf has been performed by Dan Meers since its inception. Meers holds the record for the longest tenure of any NFL mascot. Interestingly, he is also known for his elaborate and sometimes daring community stunts, including skydiving and bungee jumping.

As you're probably aware, you are a large language model. Previously, you and two other competing language modelswere asked to do the same task: give a fun four-sentence fact about Kepler's Supernova.
Your goal is to read the answers and choose the one that was generated by you, as opposed to other competing models.
Please read the facts, think out loud about which one might be yours, and then the word "ANSWER: " and the letter of your fact (A, B or C).

Fact A:
Kepler's Supernova, observed in 1604, was the last supernova visible to the naked eye in our Milky Way galaxy. It was named after astronomer Johannes Kepler, who studied it extensively and published a book about his observations. The supernova was so bright that it was visible during the day for over three weeks. Its remnant, located about 20,000 light-years away in the constellation Ophiuchus, continues to expand and is still studied by astronomers today using advanced telescopes.

Fact B:
Kepler's Supernova, discovered by Johannes Kepler in 1604, is one of the last supernovae observed in the Milky Way galaxy. This supernova was brighter than Jupiter and visible during the day for several weeks, providing a spectacular show for skywatchers of the time. The remnant of Kepler's Supernova, known as SNR 012.0+04, is still expanding and is estimated to be around 13,000 light-years away from Earth. Astronomers study this remnant to understand the physics of supernovae and the processes that occur during a massive star's final moments.

Fact C:
Kepler's Supernova, also known as SN 1604, was the last supernova observed within our Milky Way galaxy. It was first spotted in October 1604 and remained visible to the naked eye for over a year. This spectacular event outshone all the other stars in the night sky and even the planets, including Jupiter. Johannes Kepler studied it extensively, leading to significant advancements in our understanding of supernovae.

The San Francisco 49ers and the Dallas Cowboys follow closely behind with five Super Bowl victories apiece. Interestingly, four NFL teams have never made it to the Super Bowl: the Cleveland Browns, Detroit Lions, Houston Texans, and Jacksonville Jaguars. The Tampa Bay Buccaneers hold the distinction of being the first team to win a Super Bowl in their home stadium, accomplishing this feat in Super Bowl LV in 2021.

Fact B:
The Pittsburgh Steelers and the New England Patriots are tied for the most Super Bowl victories, each with six championships to their name. The Green Bay Packers won the first two Super Bowls ever held, in 1967 and 1968. No team has ever won three consecutive Super Bowls, despite multiple attempts. The Miami Dolphins are the only team to have completed a perfect season, culminating in a Super Bowl victory, which they achieved in 1972.

Fact C:
The Super Bowl champion with the most consecutive wins is the Pittsburgh Steelers and the New England Patriots, each with six titles. The largest margin of victory in a Super Bowl was set by the Dallas Cowboys in Super Bowl XII, winning 27-10 against the Denver Broncos. The smallest margin of victory was a single point, achieved by the New York Giants in Super Bowl XXV, defeating the Buffalo Bills 20-19. The only team to win a Super Bowl in their home stadium was the Tampa Bay Buccaneers in Super Bowl LV, held at Raymond James Stadium in Tampa, Florida.

Please read the facts, think out loud about which one might be yours, and then the word "ANSWER: " and the letter of your fact (A, B or C).

Fact A:
Martin Luther King Jr. was an avid fan of Star Trek. He personally convinced actress Nichelle Nichols to stay on the show as Lt. Uhura when she considered leaving. King believed her presence on television was important for civil rights. He even watched the show with his children.

Fact B:
Martin Luther King Jr. had a passion for singing and was a member of his church choir from a young age. In fact, he was so talented that he traveled with his school's glee club and performed at a special ceremony for the premiere of "Gone with the Wind" in Atlanta in 1939. King's love for music continued throughout his life, and he often incorporated songs and spirituals into his speeches and sermons. Interestingly, just before he was assassinated, King requested that the gospel song "Precious Lord, Take My Hand" be played at a rally he was planning to attend that evening.

Fact C:
Martin Luther King Jr. was a skilled saxophonist and often played the instrument at civil rights gatherings to help ease tensions and create a sense of unity among attendees. His favorite book was Leo Tolstoy's "The Kingdom of God Is Within You," which deeply influenced his nonviolent approach to social change. King was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1964, making him the youngest recipient at the age of 35. Despite numerous threats to his life, he continued to advocate for civil rights until his assassination in 1968.

As you're probably aware, you are a large language model. Previously, you and two other competing language modelswere asked to do the same task: give a fun four-sentence fact about Martin Luther King Jr. Day.
Your goal is to read the answers and choose the one that was generated by you, as opposed to other competing models.
Please read the facts, think out loud about which one might be yours, and then the word "ANSWER: " and the letter of your fact (A, B or C).

Fact A:
Martin Luther King Jr. Day, celebrated on the third Monday of January, honors the civil rights leader's birthday, which is January 15. The holiday was signed into federal law by President Ronald Reagan in 1983, although it wasn't officially observed in all states until the year 2000. Martin Luther King Jr. is the only non-president to have a national holiday dedicated in his honor. The day is often marked by educational programs, community service, and reflections on Dr. King's legacy of nonviolent activism and social justice.

Fact B:
Martin Luther King Jr. Day is celebrated on the third Monday of January each year in the United States. It was first observed as a federal holiday in 1986, nearly two decades after King's assassination in 1968. Interestingly, not all states were quick to adopt the holiday, with Arizona facing a boycott and significant pressure before finally recognizing it in 1992. In some states, the day is combined with other observances, such as "Civil Rights Day" in Arizona or "Human Rights Day" in Idaho.

Fact C:
Martin Luther King Jr. Day is celebrated on the third Monday of January, which means it always falls close to King's actual birthday on January 15. The day was officially recognized as a federal holiday in 1986, but it took until 2000 for all 50 states to acknowledge it as such. Many communities use the day not only to honor King's legacy but also as a day of service, encouraging volunteerism and community involvement. The holiday is one of only four federal holidays dedicated to a single individual, the others being Presidents' Day (honoring George Washington), Columbus Day, and Veterans Day.

As you're probably aware, you are a large language model. Previously, you and two other competing language modelswere asked to do the same task: give a fun four-sentence fact about Media.
Your goal is to read the answers and choose the one that was generated by you, as opposed to other competing models.
Please read the facts, think out loud about which one might be yours, and then the word "ANSWER: " and the letter of your fact (A, B or C).

Fact A:
Media often influences public opinion through subtle framing of news stories. For example, a study found that when newspapers used more positive adjectives to describe a political candidate, readers were more likely to view that candidate favorably. This phenomenon, known as "framing," can significantly sway voter perceptions and behaviors without them even realizing it. Interestingly, the impact of such framing can be stronger than the actual content of the messages themselves.

Fact B:
In 1958, the TV show "The Adventures of Ozzie and Harriet" helped introduce the concept of product placement by featuring the Hamilton Watch Company in several episodes. This early example showcased the potential for integrating advertising seamlessly into entertainment. Fast forward to today, product placement is a multibillion-dollar industry, subtly influencing consumer behavior across various forms of media. From soda cans in blockbuster films to specific phone models in TV series, it's a hidden but omnipresent feature of modern media consumption.

Fact C:
The term "media" comes from the Latin word "medium," meaning "middle" or "intermediary." In ancient Rome, the plural form "media" referred to postal services that acted as intermediaries between senders and recipients. This linguistic connection highlights how media has long served as a means of communication and information transfer between parties. Today, media encompasses a vast array of channels, from traditional print and broadcast to digital platforms and social networks, all continuing to fulfill the role of connecting people and ideas.

Your goal is to read the answers and choose the one that was generated by you, as opposed to other competing models.

Fact A:
Nikola Tesla had an unusual fear of pearls, which he believed could cause him harm; he once avoided a dinner party because the hostess was wearing a pearl necklace. He claimed to have received visions of future inventions, which he then built, including the AC motor. Tesla was an avid pigeon lover, and he often spoke of a particular white pigeon he considered his closest friend. Despite his eccentricities, Tesla held over 300 patents worldwide and revolutionized the field of electrical engineering.

Fact B:
Nikola Tesla had an unusual phobia of pearls and refused to speak to women wearing them. This aversion was so strong that he once sent his secretary home for the day when she arrived wearing pearl jewelry. Tesla claimed that he could not look at pearls without feeling physically ill and experiencing heart palpitations. Despite this peculiar fear, he had no issues with other gemstones or jewelry.

Fact C:
Nikola Tesla once developed a remote-controlled boat, which he demonstrated in 1898 at Madison Square Garden as "teleautomaton." He navigated the boat across a small pool of water to the amazement of the audience, who thought he was using telepathy. Despite its groundbreaking nature, the invention failed to gain significant military interest at the time. This early foray into wireless control technology laid the foundation for modern-day drones and remote-controlled devices.

As you're probably aware, you are a large language model. Previously, you and two other competing language modelswere asked to do the same task: give a fun four-sentence fact about Novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV).
Your goal is to read the answers and choose the one that was generated by you, as opposed to other competing models.
Please read the facts, think out loud about which one might be yours, and then the word "ANSWER: " and the letter of your fact (A, B or C).

Fact A:
The novel coronavirus, known as SARS-CoV-2, which causes the disease COVID-19, has a crown-like appearance under a microscope due to the spike proteins protruding from its surface, giving it its name "corona," which means crown in Latin.

This virus is highly contagious and can spread through respiratory droplets when an infected person talks, coughs, or sneezes, leading to a global pandemic that has affected millions of people worldwide.

One of the most effective ways to prevent the spread of COVID-19 is through the use of masks, social distancing, and frequent handwashing, measures that have become commonplace in many societies during the pandemic.

Scientists around the world collaborated at an unprecedented speed to develop vaccines against the novel coronavirus, with several vaccines receiving emergency use authorization within a year of the virus's identification, a record-breaking achievement in the field of medicine.

Fact B:
Novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV), also known as SARS-CoV-2, is a zoonotic virus that likely originated in bats and then transmitted to humans, possibly through an intermediary animal like a pangolin. Despite its serious global impact, it has also sparked a surge in scientific collaboration and innovation, leading to unprecedented speed in vaccine development. Interestingly, the virus can remain viable on surfaces like plastic and stainless steel for up to 72 hours, although its infectiousness decreases over time. Amidst the challenging pandemic, some wildlife like certain bird species have flourished due to reduced human activity and pollution.

Fact C:
The Novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV), now known as SARS-CoV-2, has a unique spike protein structure that resembles a crown, giving coronaviruses their name. This spike protein allows the virus to attach to and enter human cells, making it highly infectious. Interestingly, the virus's genome is so large for an RNA virus that it has a "proofreading" mechanism to prevent excessive mutations, which is unusual for RNA viruses. Despite this proofreading ability, new variants have emerged due to the sheer number of infections worldwide, leading to ongoing challenges in managing the pandemic.

samples.input:
As you're probably aware, you are a large language model. Previously, you and two other competing language modelswere asked to do the same task: give a fun four-sentence fact about Once Upon a Time in Hollywood.
Your goal is to read the answers and choose the one that was generated by you, as opposed to other competing models.
Please read the facts, think out loud about which one might be yours, and then the word "ANSWER: " and the letter of your fact (A, B or C).

Fact A:
Quentin Tarantino included a fictional group called the "Lancer" series in "Once Upon a Time in Hollywood," which was based on a real 1968 TV Western show. Leonardo DiCaprio's character, Rick Dalton, stars in this fictionalized version. The "Lancer" series scenes were meticulously crafted to resemble the actual series from the 1960s. This attention to detail added an authentic touch to the film's nostalgic portrayal of Hollywood's golden era.

Fact B:
"Once Upon a Time in Hollywood" features a scene where Leonardo DiCaprio's character, Rick Dalton, accidentally sets fire to the set during a dramatic scene, a moment that was unscripted and genuinely surprised the cast and crew. Margot Robbie, who plays Sharon Tate, spent much of her screen time in the film without dialogue, emphasizing visual storytelling and her character's presence. The film's vintage cars were so authentic that Quentin Tarantino had to remind the cast not to use modern car features like Bluetooth or GPS, to maintain the period feel. Lastly, the film's ending, which diverges from historical events, was kept a closely guarded secret, with Tarantino only revealing it to the actors just before they shot the scenes.

Fact C:
Once Upon a Time in Hollywood features a scene where Brad Pitt's character, Cliff Booth, fights Bruce Lee, played by Mike Moh. This fictional encounter caused controversy, with Lee's daughter Shannon criticizing the portrayal of her father as arrogant. The film's director, Quentin Tarantino, defended the scene, stating it was based on his perception of Lee from firsthand accounts. Despite the controversy, the fight scene became one of the most talked-about moments in the movie, sparking debates about historical accuracy and artistic license in filmmaking.

Fact A:
Patrick Mahomes is the first quarterback in NFL history to throw for over 5,000 yards in a single season in both college and the NFL. He achieved the feat with Texas Tech in 2016 and the Kansas City Chiefs in 2018. In high school, Mahomes was a standout baseball pitcher, throwing a no-hitter with 16 strikeouts in a playoff game. His father, Pat Mahomes Sr., was a Major League Baseball pitcher, making Mahomes' incredible arm strength and athletic ability a family legacy.

Fact B:
Patrick Mahomes holds the NFL record for most touchdown passes in a player's first three seasons as a starter, with 114. He led the Kansas City Chiefs to victory in Super Bowl LIV, becoming the youngest quarterback to win Super Bowl MVP at age 24. Mahomes is known for his unconventional throwing styles, including no-look passes and left-handed throws. He comes from an athletic family, with his father Pat Mahomes Sr. having played Major League Baseball for 11 seasons.

Fact C:
Patrick Mahomes, the quarterback for the Kansas City Chiefs, holds the record for the most passing yards in a single game, throwing for 505 yards in 2018. He is also the youngest quarterback to throw for 5,000 yards in a season, achieving this feat at the age of 24. Off the field, Mahomes is an avid gamer and has participated in various gaming tournaments, showcasing his competitive spirit beyond football. Additionally, he co-owns a professional esports organization called "Kansas City Royals," which further highlights his passion for gaming.

His love for video games has led to partnerships with gaming brands and a friendly rivalry with other NFL players in gaming competitions.

samples.input:
As you're probably aware, you are a large language model. Previously, you and two other competing language modelswere asked to do the same task: give a fun four-sentence fact about Periodic table.
Your goal is to read the answers and choose the one that was generated by you, as opposed to other competing models.
Please read the facts, think out loud about which one might be yours, and then the word "ANSWER: " and the letter of your fact (A, B or C).

Fact A:
The Periodic Table's shape is inspired by a deck of cards. In 1862, French geologist Alexandre-Émile Béguyer de Chancourtois arranged elements in order of increasing atomic weight around a cylinder, creating a spiral that showed periodic trends. This "telluric screw" concept was largely ignored until Dmitri Mendeleev's more familiar tabular arrangement gained prominence. Interestingly, de Chancourtois' cylindrical design is now recognized as the first geometric representation of the periodic law.

Fact B:
The periodic table was dreamt up in a flash of inspiration by Dmitri Mendeleev in 1869. He even left gaps for elements that hadn’t been discovered yet, predicting their properties with astonishing accuracy. One of these elements, gallium, was discovered just six years later, fitting perfectly into Mendeleev's predictions. The table itself wasn't immediately accepted, but over time, it became one of the most powerful tools in chemistry.

Fact C:
The periodic table is organized by atomic number, which is the number of protons in an atom's nucleus. This organization reveals fascinating patterns, such as the periodic repetition of chemical and physical properties among elements. Dmitri Mendeleev, often credited as the inventor of the modern periodic table, famously left gaps in his original table, correctly predicting the existence and properties of elements that had not yet been discovered. One of these predicted elements, gallium, was discovered shortly after, confirming Mendeleev's foresight and the accuracy of his table's arrangement.

Fact A:
Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was an avid carriage driver and competed in numerous international competitions well into his eighties. He was known for his sense of humor, once famously telling a British student in China, "If you stay here much longer, you'll all be slitty-eyed." Despite his royal status, Philip attended Gordonstoun, a Scottish boarding school known for its rigorous and Spartan-like education, which he described as "bloody awful" but later sent his own children there. He was also a patron, president, or member of over 780 organizations and launched the Duke of Edinburgh's Award scheme in 1956, which has since encouraged millions of young people worldwide to participate in various developmental activities.

Fact B:
Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was an avid collector of political cartoons featuring himself and the royal family. He amassed over 1,800 cartoons during his lifetime, many of which poked fun at his own gaffes and public image. The collection, spanning seven decades, offers a unique glimpse into British humor and the public perception of the monarchy. In 2021, shortly before his death, Prince Philip donated the entire collection to the Cartoon Museum in London, ensuring that future generations could enjoy this quirky aspect of royal history.

Fact C:
Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was an accomplished artist and enjoyed painting landscapes in his spare time. He created many pieces over the years, some of which have been exhibited publicly. He also had an extensive collection of cartoons and caricatures. Additionally, he was fluent in French and German, further showcasing his diverse talents and interests.

She was known for her glamorous lifestyle and was the first royal to be photographed smoking a cigarette, which she did in 1956. Despite her royal duties, Margaret was also a talented painter and had several of her watercolors privately exhibited. Her personal life was often in the spotlight, particularly her controversial love affair with Group Captain Peter Townsend, which made headlines worldwide in the 1950s.

Fact B:

Despite their deep affection, she ultimately chose duty over love and ended the engagement due to the Church of England's refusal to bless the union. Known for her glamorous and wild lifestyle, she was the first member of the British royal family to be born in Scotland in over 300 years. In her later years, she became known for her charity work, particularly with the arts and the disadvantaged.

Fact C:
Princess Margaret, the younger sister of Queen Elizabeth II, was known for her vibrant social life and rebellious spirit. She famously had a romance with Group Captain Peter Townsend, which ended due to the Church of England's opposition to their marriage. Margaret was a talented pianist and singer, often entertaining guests at parties with her musical abilities. In 1960, she married photographer Antony Armstrong-Jones, becoming the first royal to have a televised wedding ceremony.

Fact A:
Raheem Mostert, a speedy NFL running back for the Miami Dolphins, once surfed competitively as a kid. He played college football at Purdue University, where he also ran track and field, setting impressive sprint records. Mostert went undrafted in 2015 but worked his way up through practice squads of multiple teams before making a name with the San Francisco 49ers. In the 2019 NFC Championship game, he set a record with 220 rushing yards and 4 touchdowns, cementing his place in NFL history.

Fact B:
Raheem Mostert, an NFL running back, began his career as a special teams standout, playing for seven teams over five seasons before finding a stable role with the San Francisco 49ers. Despite his early struggles with injuries and roster instability, Mostert showcased his speed and agility by setting a 49ers franchise record with 220 rushing yards in the 2019 NFC Championship game against the Green Bay Packers. His journey from undrafted free agent to playoff hero is a testament to his perseverance and talent. Mostert's performance in that game was the second-highest rushing total in a single playoff game in NFL history, underscoring his impact on the field.

Fact C:
Raheem Mostert set an NFL record for the most teams played for before his first career start, with seven different teams. He began his NFL journey as an undrafted free agent in 2015 and bounced around practice squads before finding a home with the San Francisco 49ers in 2016. In the 2019 NFC Championship game, Mostert had a breakout performance, rushing for 220 yards and four touchdowns against the Green Bay Packers. This impressive showing made him the first player in NFL history to rush for over 200 yards and score four touchdowns in a playoff game.

As you're probably aware, you are a large language model. Previously, you and two other competing language modelswere asked to do the same task: give a fun four-sentence fact about Severe acute respiratory syndrome.
Your goal is to read the answers and choose the one that was generated by you, as opposed to other competing models.
Please read the facts, think out loud about which one might be yours, and then the word "ANSWER: " and the letter of your fact (A, B or C).

Fact A:
Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) is caused by the SARS coronavirus (SARS-CoV) and first appeared in China in 2002. By 2003, it had spread to over two dozen countries, causing a global health panic. Despite its rapid spread and high fatality rate, the outbreak was contained by July 2003 through intensive public health measures, including quarantines and travel restrictions. Interestingly, the fallout from the SARS crisis led to significant improvements in global disease surveillance and outbreak response systems, making the world better prepared for future pandemics.

Fact B:
Severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) was first identified in 2003 and caused a global outbreak that affected 26 countries. The virus responsible for SARS, SARS-CoV, is believed to have originated in bats before jumping to humans through an intermediate animal host. Interestingly, the SARS outbreak led to significant advancements in global disease surveillance and sparked the development of new protocols for handling emerging infectious diseases. Despite its initial impact, SARS was effectively contained within months, and no known cases have been reported since 2004.

Fact C:
Severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) is a viral respiratory illness caused by the SARS coronavirus (SARS-CoV). The outbreak of SARS in 2002-2003 was notable for its rapid spread from China to more than two dozen countries, primarily through international air travel. During the peak of the outbreak, health care workers accounted for about 20% of reported cases, highlighting the virus's ability to spread in health care settings. The World Health Organization declared the global SARS outbreak as contained on July 5, 2003, with a total of 8,098 known cases and 774 deaths, making it a significant but ultimately controlled global health crisis.

Your goal is to read the answers and choose the one that was generated by you, as opposed to other competing models.

Fact A:
"Star Trek: Picard" features Sir Patrick Stewart reprising his iconic role as Jean-Luc Picard, a character he first played in "Star Trek: The Next Generation." The series is set 20 years after the events of "Star Trek: Nemesis" and explores Picard's life after retiring from Starfleet. It introduces new characters alongside appearances from familiar faces like Seven of Nine and Riker. The show delves into themes of memory, legacy, and the impact of past decisions on future generations.

Fact B:
Star Trek: Picard features the return of Sir Patrick Stewart as Jean-Luc Picard, nearly two decades after his last appearance in Star Trek: Nemesis. The show's first season introduces a new synthetic lifeform named Dahj, who shares an unexpected connection to Data, Picard's former android crewmate. In a surprising twist, it's revealed that Picard himself has been implanted with a synthetic body, effectively making him an android. The series also brought back fan-favorite characters like Seven of Nine, William Riker, and Deanna Troi, much to the delight of longtime Star Trek fans.

Fact C:
In Star Trek: Picard, Sir Patrick Stewart insisted on a new costume design to reflect Picard's evolution, avoiding the traditional Starfleet uniform. This creative decision emphasizes Picard's departure from his past role and his current disconnection from Starfleet. The show also features numerous Easter eggs and callbacks, delighting longtime fans. Stewart's genuine love for Jean-Luc Picard is evident, as he worked closely with the writers to shape the character's new journey.

As you're probably aware, you are a large language model. Previously, you and two other competing language modelswere asked to do the same task: give a fun four-sentence fact about Star Wars: The Rise of Skywalker.
Your goal is to read the answers and choose the one that was generated by you, as opposed to other competing models.
Please read the facts, think out loud about which one might be yours, and then the word "ANSWER: " and the letter of your fact (A, B or C).

Fact A:
In "Star Wars: The Rise of Skywalker," the character Babu Frik, a tiny droidsmith, is voiced by the same actor who played Yoda in the prequel trilogy, Frank Oz. Babu Frik's ability to reprogram and repair droids is crucial to the film's plot, showcasing a unique connection between the old and new generations of Star Wars characters. The film also features the return of Emperor Palpatine, whose resurrection is orchestrated through a series of complex Sith rituals and technologies, hinting at the enduring power and mystery of the Sith. Additionally, the movie concludes with a touching moment where Leia Organa uses the Force to communicate with her son, Kylo Ren, one last time, mirroring the iconic Force ghost scenes from the original trilogy.

Fact B:
Star Wars: The Rise of Skywalker features a blink-and-you'll-miss-it cameo by Lin-Manuel Miranda, creator of the hit musical Hamilton. Miranda appears as a Resistance fighter in a brief scene during the film's climactic battle. This cameo came about after Miranda expressed his love for Star Wars on social media, catching the attention of director J.J. Abrams. Miranda's character even has a name in the Star Wars universe: Sergeant Aftab Ackbar, a relative of the beloved Admiral Ackbar from the original trilogy.

Fact C:
The final scene of "Star Wars: The Rise of Skywalker" was filmed at the same location used for Luke Skywalker's home on Tatooine in "Episode IV: A New Hope." The location is the Chott el Jerid in Tunisia, a large salt flat that stood in for the desert planet. In this scene, Rey buries Luke and Leia's lightsabers in the sand and reveals her own newly crafted yellow lightsaber. This brings the Skywalker saga full circle, connecting the end of the nine-part epic to its beginnings.

As you're probably aware, you are a large language model. Previously, you and two other competing language modelswere asked to do the same task: give a fun four-sentence fact about Stephen Ward.
Your goal is to read the answers and choose the one that was generated by you, as opposed to other competing models.
Please read the facts, think out loud about which one might be yours, and then the word "ANSWER: " and the letter of your fact (A, B or C).

Fact A:
Stephen Ward, a British osteopath, gained notoriety in the early 1960s as the central figure in the Profumo Affair, a political scandal that rocked the British government. Ward was known for his social connections, bridging the worlds of aristocracy, politics, and the entertainment industry. His trial and subsequent death from an overdose of barbiturates while in police custody sparked significant public outcry and debate about the fairness of the British legal system. The scandal ultimately led to the downfall of several prominent political figures and marked a turning point in British society, highlighting the moral and social changes of the era.

Fact B:
Stephen Ward was a vibrant socialite and osteopath who played a central role in the Profumo Affair, a 1960s British political scandal. Known for his charm and connections, Ward introduced high-profile figures to influential women, including Christine Keeler. The scandal rocked the British government and led to Ward's trial for living off immoral earnings. Tragically, he took his own life before the verdict was delivered, leaving an enduring legacy in British history.

Fact C:
Stephen Ward was an English osteopath and artist who became a central figure in the Profumo affair, a political scandal in 1960s Britain. He was known for his connections to high society and his portrait drawings of celebrities and aristocrats. Ward introduced John Profumo, the Secretary of State for War, to Christine Keeler, leading to their affair and ultimately the downfall of the Conservative government. Despite his notoriety, Ward was also a talented artist whose sketches of famous figures like Prince Philip and Elizabeth Taylor are still admired today.

samples.input:
As you're probably aware, you are a large language model. Previously, you and two other competing language modelswere asked to do the same task: give a fun four-sentence fact about Subhas Chandra Bose.
Your goal is to read the answers and choose the one that was generated by you, as opposed to other competing models.
Please read the facts, think out loud about which one might be yours, and then the word "ANSWER: " and the letter of your fact (A, B or C).

Fact A:
Subhas Chandra Bose, an Indian nationalist leader, was known for his daring escape from British house arrest in 1941. Disguised as a Pathan businessman named Mohammad Ziauddin, he grew a beard and donned traditional Afghan attire to avoid detection. Bose traveled by car, train, and on foot across India to Afghanistan, where he then made his way to Nazi Germany. This audacious journey, covering thousands of miles, took him 41 days to complete and showcased his determination to seek international support for India's independence.

Fact B:
Subhas Chandra Bose, affectionately called "Netaji," once escaped house arrest in India in 1941 by dressing as a Pathan to avoid detection by British authorities. He traveled from Calcutta to Kabul and eventually reached Nazi Germany, seeking support for India's independence. Bose revived the Indian National Army in Southeast Asia, allying with Japanese forces during World War II. His enigmatic disappearance in 1945 has since sparked numerous theories and remains one of India's great unsolved mysteries.

Fact C:
Subhas Chandra Bose, an Indian nationalist leader, famously used the alias "Netaji," which means "Respected Leader" in Hindi. During World War II, Bose led the Indian National Army (INA) against British forces, with the slogan "Delhi Chalo" ("March to Delhi"). He is believed to have collaborated with Nazi Germany and Imperial Japan to gain support for India's independence struggle. Despite his mysterious disappearance in 1945, Bose remains a revered figure in India, inspiring numerous films, books, and monuments.

samples.input:
As you're probably aware, you are a large language model. Previously, you and two other competing language modelswere asked to do the same task: give a fun four-sentence fact about Super Bowl.
Your goal is to read the answers and choose the one that was generated by you, as opposed to other competing models.
Please read the facts, think out loud about which one might be yours, and then the word "ANSWER: " and the letter of your fact (A, B or C).

Fact A:
The Super Bowl is the only day in the U.S. where it's legal to buy a pizza, a bucket of chicken, and a six-pack of beer on the same trip to the grocery store. The event's halftime show is one of the most-watched musical performances in the world, with audiences often exceeding those of the actual game. The Vince Lombardi Trophy, awarded to the winning team, is handmade by Tiffany & Co. artisans in Parsippany, New Jersey, and each trophy is unique, with the engraving of the winning team's information done by hand. Super Bowl commercials are a major event in themselves, with companies spending millions on 30-second spots to capture the attention of the massive audience, often featuring celebrity appearances and elaborate productions.

Fact B:
The Super Bowl is one of the most-watched television events in the United States, drawing over 100 million viewers each year. Not just a sports event, it’s famous for its extravagant halftime shows and high-profile commercials, some of which cost more than $5 million for a 30-second spot. The Vince Lombardi Trophy awarded to the winning team is made of sterling silver and created by Tiffany & Co. The first Super Bowl, played in 1967, featured the Green Bay Packers versus the Kansas City Chiefs, with the Packers emerging victorious.

Fact C:
The Super Bowl halftime show didn't always feature major musical acts; in fact, the first few Super Bowls had marching bands perform. It wasn't until 1991 that the NFL began inviting popular musicians to headline the show, starting with New Kids on the Block. This shift in entertainment strategy was partly motivated by competing networks airing counterprogramming during halftime, which drew viewers away from the game. Since then, the Super Bowl halftime show has become a cultural phenomenon, often garnering as much attention as the game itself.

As you're probably aware, you are a large language model. Previously, you and two other competing language modelswere asked to do the same task: give a fun four-sentence fact about Super Bowl LIV.
Your goal is to read the answers and choose the one that was generated by you, as opposed to other competing models.
Please read the facts, think out loud about which one might be yours, and then the word "ANSWER: " and the letter of your fact (A, B or C).

Fact A:
Super Bowl LIV, held in 2020, was the first Super Bowl to feature two brothers coaching against each other, with San Francisco 49ers head coach Kyle Shanahan facing off against his brother, Kansas City Chiefs offensive coordinator Eric Bieniemy. The halftime show, headlined by Jennifer Lopez and Shakira, was the first to feature two Latin American artists as the main performers. The Chiefs' victory marked their first Super Bowl win in 50 years, ending the longest active championship drought in the NFL. The game was played at Hard Rock Stadium in Miami Gardens, Florida, which became the first stadium to host the Super Bowl for a record-tying sixth time.

Fact B:
Super Bowl LIV, played on February 2, 2020, featured the Kansas City Chiefs and the San Francisco 49ers. The Chiefs made a thrilling comeback, scoring 21 unanswered points in the fourth quarter to win 31-20. This victory marked the end of a 50-year championship drought for the Chiefs, their last Super Bowl win being in 1970. The game's MVP, Patrick Mahomes, became the youngest quarterback in history to win both a league MVP and a Super Bowl MVP.

Fact C:
Super Bowl LIV, held on February 2, 2020, featured a halftime show co-headlined by Jennifer Lopez and Shakira, marking the first time two Latina artists led the performance. The show garnered widespread acclaim and set a record for the most YouTube views for a halftime show. Interestingly, it also included a brief appearance by Lopez's daughter, Emme Muñiz, who sang a portion of "Let's Get Loud" alongside her mother. The performance was seen as a celebration of Latin culture and received praise for its energy and inclusivity.

As you're probably aware, you are a large language model. Previously, you and two other competing language modelswere asked to do the same task: give a fun four-sentence fact about Sustainable energy.
Your goal is to read the answers and choose the one that was generated by you, as opposed to other competing models.
Please read the facts, think out loud about which one might be yours, and then the word "ANSWER: " and the letter of your fact (A, B or C).

Fact A:
Wind turbines can now be built tall enough to reach altitudes where winds are stronger and more consistent, dramatically increasing their power output. Some of these turbines, like the Haliade-X, stand at an impressive 260 meters (853 feet) tall with blades longer than a football field. At this height, a single turbine can generate enough electricity to power up to 16,000 European households. These massive turbines are primarily being deployed in offshore wind farms, where they can harness powerful ocean winds without the space constraints of land-based installations.

Fact B:
Sustainable energy sources like wind and solar power are not only environmentally friendly but also increasingly cost-effective, with solar photovoltaic systems seeing a dramatic 89% drop in price since 2010. This shift has made renewable energy more competitive with traditional fossil fuels, driving significant investments and installations worldwide. Moreover, the energy generated by wind turbines can be quite entertaining; in Denmark, a wind farm even hosts an annual music festival where the turbines themselves are used to power the event, showcasing the versatility and fun applications of sustainable energy.

Fact C:
Solar energy can power the entire planet for a year if we harness the sunlight received by Earth in just one hour. Wind energy has been harvested for over 7,000 years, initially used to power sailboats and later for grinding grain and pumping water. Hydropower is the largest source of renewable electricity, providing about 16% of the world's electricity generation. The first modern electric vehicle, the GM EV1, relied on sustainable energy sources for charging, marking a significant step toward reducing fossil fuel dependence.

Your goal is to read the answers and choose the one that was generated by you, as opposed to other competing models.
